items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has 16 pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment. The District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District. In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers.  Proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund. 
 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The project consists of replacing existing high bay lighting at gymnasium buildings 2500 and 2600 at Foothill College with LED light fixtures.
	 
Gayneer Engineers prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid #1700 was legally advertised on December 16 and December 23, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at govbids.com.  A non-mandatory bid walk was held on Jan. 6, 2015, eleven (11) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on Jan. 15, 2015 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
CONTRACTORS
BASE BID PROPOSAL AMOUNT
E.R. Brothers Company Inc.
$134,380
Shank Electric
$140,172
National Electric, Inc. 
$149,850
ARAM Electric, Inc. 
$151.000
Rosendin Electric, Inc.
$155,980
Delgado Electric, Inc.
$162,500
Joseph Cumiskey Construction Corp. 
$168,000
Atlas/Pellizzari Electric, Inc.
$179,000
BASS Electric
$181.375
	 
	 
The apparent low bidder, E.R. Brothers Company Inc. (ER Brothers) did not acknowledge receipt of Amendment #1 and did not submit its bid on the revised bid proposal form issued as a part of Amendment #1.  The bid document states in Document 00 21 13, Instructions to Bidders, Item #10 - District's Right to Modify Bid Documents, “the failure of any Bidder to acknowledge such amendments in its Bid Proposal will render the Bid Proposal non-responsive and rejected.”   The second apparent low bidder, Shank Electric’s contractor license was not valid at the time of the bid opening.  The bid document states in Document 00 21 13, Instructions to Bidders, Item #17 - Contractor’s License,  “No Bid Proposal will be considered from a Bidder who, at the time Bid Proposals are opened, is not licensed to perform the Work of the Contract Documents, in accordance with the Contractors License Law, California Business & Professions Code §§7000 et seq.  This requirement is not a mere formality and will not be waived by the District or its Board of Trustees.”  
	 
District staff consulted with its legal counsel Mr. Phillip Jaret of Jaret & Jaret Attorneys at Law regarding these issues and it is the opinion of staff and legal counsel that ER Brothers not acknowledging the amendment and Shank Electric's license being suspended are not minor irregularities that can be waived.  Therefore, the bid proposals submitted by ER Brothers and Shank Electric must be rejected as non-responsive. 
	 
The apparent third lowest responsive and responsible bidder is National Electric, Inc. (National).   National acknowledged Amendment #1, however National did not submit its bid on the Revised Bid Proposal form issued as part of Amendment #1.   Purchasing Services consulted with District’s legal counsel, Mr. Phillip Jaret, regarding the bid submitted on the incorrect form and it is his opinion that the failure of National to submit its pricing on the incorrect form does not make any material changes to the bid pricing, therefore, it is a minor irregularity that can be waived by the District.  
	 
National has successfully completed projects for other public entities such as the City of Hayward, Leitch Elementary School and Azevada Elementary School. 
	 
The bid price of $149,850 submitted by National Electric Inc. is within the construction estimate of $195,500.  This project will be funded by Proposition 39: California Clean Energy Jobs Act, Year 1 and Year 2 Funding
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Steve Kitchen, Jennifer Mahato, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Reject the bid submitted by E.R. Brothers Company Inc. and Shank Electric as non-responsive, waive the minor irregularity in the National Electric, Inc. response to Bid #1700, and authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, to award a contract pursuant to Bid #1700, High Bay Lighting Upgrade at Gymnasiums Buildings 2500 and 2600 in the amount of $149,850 to National Electric, Inc.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
  
During the course of demolition and in preparation for construction, it was found much of the existing flexible ductwork was constructed with un-reinforced, un-lined fiberglass duct board and it was not a product that can be cleaned. These ducts were part of the original building construction and they are beyond their useful life. Due to this type of ductwork, the Architect has advised that replacing all of the existing duct at the 2nd floor would be the most cost effective and prudent long-term option.  
	 
Due to the expedited nature of this work, the time allowed for the project team to request authorization from the Board of Trustees for authorization to negotiate change orders in excess of $50,000 has been extremely constrained. This Board of Trustees action item requests that the Board approve the project team to continue with negotiations with the Contractor to confirm the fixed costs and determine if any additional time is allowable to extend the duration of this new work in the project schedule, or, to request a specific amount of overtime to bring the project back on the approved scheduled completion.
	 
To date, the Architectâs design team developed plans for the removal and replacement of the duct and the project team has been negotiating the best approach to perform the work with the Contractor as well as the cost component. The project completion date has been set at July 12, 2015, and does not allow for a schedule impact without negatively affecting the College operations. Change Order #2 is being presented in the amount of $658,565 for procurement and complete installation of the new duct only and no time extension is included in this Change Order #2. The Contractor will provide a time impact analysis schedule for review by the project team to determine if the contract completion date shall be extended or if overtime is necessary. The project team will negotiate added costs if necessary to bring the schedule back to the July 12, 2015, date. This Change Order #2 that covers PCO #9 is also based on the Contractor and their subcontractor not working overtime to complete this additional work.

Background and Analysis:
	 
This is a modified rebid of Project 162 that includes the replacement of site stairs linking Lot 1 with Smithwick Theater and the campus beyond. The work generally involves demolition of existing stairs, site grading, new concrete landings, on-grade and elevated stairs, and new lighting.
	 
WRNS Studio prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on November 25, 2014 and December 2, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on December 10, 2014, and a total of five (5) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on January 13, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office.  Four (4) contractors submitted bids and the bid proposal amounts are summarized below:
	 
BID RESULTS
	 
Contractor
Total Bid Proposal Amount:
Integra Construction Services, Inc. 
$654,530
Rodan Builders, Inc.
$689,000
Granite Rock Company
$725,845
RC Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors
$771,900
	 
According to Public Contract Code (PCC), Section 20651(b): “The governing board shall let any contract for a public project, as defined in subdivision (c) of Section 22002, involving an expenditure of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) or more to the lowest responsible bidder who shall give security as the board requires, or else reject all bids.” 
	 
The lowest bid submitted exceeds the architect’s estimate of $385,000.  Therefore, the District recommends that the Board reject all bids received for Bid#1715-162, Parking and Circulation Phase 3, Lot 1 Stairs. A busy construction industry and a complex design for a portion of the stairs led to high bid costs.    
	 
A revised bid package will be prepared to simplify the design in order to reduce the project cost.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Steve Kitchen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez

No

Background and Analysis:
	 
On September 8, 2014, the Board authorized the use of the Lease-Leaseback contractor selection process for the District’s Measure C Project 404 – New District Offices in accordance with Education Code 81335. The project generally consists of a new administrative offices building and related site work.  The project may be extended to include removal of temporary modular buildings in Lot 5/6 and reconstruction of that site into a parking lot.
	 
Purchasing Services staff legally advertised the Lease-Leaseback Request for Qualifications and Request for Proposals (RFQ/RFP) #1708-404 for the New District Offices project on September 24, 2014 and October 1, 2014 in the San Jose Post Record.  Furthermore, nine (9) Builders Exchanges and Plan Rooms were notified of the RFQ/RFP and a copy of the legal advertisement was also posted online at “BidNet” at govbids.com. Purchasing Services staff also contacted over forty(40) companies regarding the RFQ/RFP opportunity. 
	 
Representatives from twenty-five (25) contractor companies attended the mandatory pre-submittal conference held on October 7, 2014. Twelve (12) contractors submitted Statements of Qualifications (SOQ) and Request for Proposals (RFP) in response to RFQ/RFP #1708-404 by the 2:00 p.m., October 31, 2014 deadline. 
	 
A Selection Committee was established to evaluate the responses to the RFQ/RFP. The five (5) member Selection Committee consisted of represenatives from: Facilities and Operations; Bond Program Management; District Project Manager; Ratcliff architects; and Purchasing Services.  The committee evaluated each of the SOQ for responsiveness that included financial capacity, safety record, and similar project experiences, and invited the five highest ranking contractors (Blach Construction, C. W. Driver, Inc., Kitchell CEM, Inc., Swinerton Builders (Swinerton), and Hathaway Dinwiddie Construction Co.) to continue with the interview and RFP process.  
	 
The Selection Committee conducted interviews on December 9th and 10th, 2014 and responses to the RFP were received and opened on January 23, 2015. The RFP responses included competitive fee proposals for preconstruction services, construction services, contractor’s contingency, and contractor’s overhead and profit.  Based on the proposals provided in relation to the scores of the RFQ and the interviews, Swinerton had the score with the lowest cost per qualification point and earned the top ranking. 
	 
The Selection Committee recommends award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement (see attached) to Swinerton so that it can develop a preliminary construction schedule, assist the architect in designing the project to budget, prequalify subcontractors for bidding, obtain competitive bids from subcontractors, and develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) for the project. Swinerton’s fee for Preconstruction Services is $75,000 for the New District Offices. The Preconstruction Services Agreement, paragraph VII(C), provides that the contractor will be reimbursed for reimbursable services such as printing and site condition confirmation. Swinerton and District staff agreed that Swinerton’s estimated reimbursable services will not exceed $25,000.  The total not to exceed cost for the Preconstruction Services Agreement is $100,000.
	 
Provided that District and Swinerton agree to a GMP, project milestone dates, and completion dates, District staff will return to the Board and recommend award of the Site Lease and Facilities Lease agreements to Swinerton to construct the Project within the agreed-upon duration for an amount not to exceed the GMP.  Under the two agreements, the District will lease District-owned land to Swinerton and in return Swinerton will agree to construct the project pursuant to the District’s Construction Provisions and Swinerton’s responses to RFQ/RFP #1708-404.  The District will receive incremental title to the constructed property in accordance with payments made.  The District will pay for and take title to all improvements no later than completion of construction of the project at which time the leases will be terminated.  These services are within the project budget and are funded by Measure C.
	 
Submitted by:
					  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Art Heinrich, Director of Bond Program Management
					  Steve Kitchen, Executive Director of Facilities & Operations
  and Gina Bailey, Senior Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
					  Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On November 3, 2014, the Board authorized the use of the Lease-Leaseback contractor selection process for the De Anza College Measure C Project 202 – L-7 Renovation in accordance with Education Code 81335. This project consists of two phases of work; Phase 1 is renovation of the L-7 Building with an optional Phase 2 to renovate the interior of the existing data center housed in L-7. 
	 
Purchasing Services staff legally advertised the Lease-Leaseback Request for Qualifications and Request for Proposals (RFQ/RFP) #1678-202 for the L-7 Renovation project on November 14 and November 20, 2014 in the San Jose Post Record.  Furthermore, nine (9) Builders Exchanges were notified of the RFQ/RFP and a copy of the legal advertisement was also posted online at “BidNet” at govbids.com. Purchasing Services staff also contacted twenty-four (24) companies regarding the RFQ/RFP opportunity. 
	 
Representatives from eleven (11) contractor companies attended the mandatory pre-submittal conference held on November 25, 2014. Four (4) contractors, Landmark Construction (Landmark), Plant Construction Company, L.P., Swenson & Associates (Swenson), Swinerton Builders (Swinerton) submitted Statements of Qualifications (SOQ) and Request for Proposals (RFP) in response to RFQ/RFP #1678-202 by the 2:00 PM, December 17, 2014 deadline. 
	 
A Selection Committee was established to evaluate the responses to the RFQ/RFP. The seven (7) member Selection Committee included representatives from: De Anza College Operations; De Anza Bond Program Management; District Project Management; ETS; Purchasing Services, and Noll & Tam Architects.  The committee evaluated each of the SOQ for responsiveness (including financial capacity, safety record, and similar project experiences) and invited the top three (3) contractors, Landmark, Swenson, and Swinerton to continue with the interview and RFP process.  
	 
The Selection Committee conducted interviews on January 14, 2015 and responses to the RFP were opened on January 20, 2015.  The RFP responses included competitive fee proposals for preconstruction services, construction services, contractor’s contingency, and contractor’s overhead and profit.  Based on the proposals provided in relation to the scores of the RFQ and the interviews, Swinerton Builders had the score with the lowest cost per qualification point and earned the top ranking. 
	 
The Selection Committee recommends award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement (see attached) to Swinerton so that it can develop a Preliminary Construction Schedule, proceed with reviewing the design documentation for constructability, prequalify subcontractors for bidding, obtain competitive bids from subcontractors, and develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) for the project. Swinerton’s fee for Preconstruction Services is $14,000. The Preconstruction Services Agreement, paragraph VII(C), provides that the contractor will be reimbursed at actual cost for reimbursable services defined as printing, advertising, and site condition confirmation. Swinerton proposed and District staff agreed that Swinerton’s estimated reimbursable services will not exceed $20,000.  The total not to exceed cost for the Preconstruction Services Agreement is $34,000.
	 
Provided that District and Swinerton agree to a GMP, project milestone dates, and completion dates indicated in the Preliminary Construction Schedule, District staff plans to return to the Board as early as April 6, 2015 and recommend award of the Site Lease and Facilities Lease agreements to Swinerton to construct Phase 1 of the L-7 Project based upon DSA-approved construction documents within the agreed-upon duration for an amount not to exceed the GMP.  Under the two agreements, the District will lease District-owned land to Swinerton and in return Swinerton will agree to construct the project pursuant to the District’s Construction Provisions and Swinerton’s responses to RFQ/RFP #1678-202.  The District will receive incremental title to the constructed property in accordance with payments made.  The District will pay for and take title to all improvements no later than completion of construction of the project at which time the leases will be terminated.  These services are within the project budget and are funded by Measure C.
	 
At the District’s request, Swinerton and the District may negotiate a Preconstruction Agreement for Phase 2 and if accepted by the District and approved by the District’s Board of Trustees, the Swinerton may sign an amended Preconstruction Agreement and commence working with the Architect to complete the plans and Specifications for Phase 2 and then bid the work to generate an acceptable GMP for the District to approve. The District will then submit the GMP for Phase 2 to the Board of Trustees for approval and, if approved, Swinerton will sign amended Lease Agreements for Phase 2 work and commence work based on the agreed-upon schedule.
	 
The anticipated scope of services, delivery dates, and the budgetary information is intended to be available for the Phase 2 effort in Spring 2015, and the anticipated construction date is Fall 2015 through Spring 2016. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director - Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Donna Jones Dulin, Steve Kitchen, Tom Armstrong, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
Yes
